customHeadContent:
<style>
  /*
  .bg-primary {
    background-color: #0c8795 !important;
  }
  .bg-warning {
    background-color: #ffff59 !important;
  }
  */
  section {
    margin-top: 20px;
  }
  section.card-body {
    margin-top: 0px;
  }
  section.card-body .form-group {
    margin-bottom: .5rem;
  }
  div.card-header > div.h5, div.card-header > div.h6 {
    margin-bottom: 0px;
  }

  .modal-dialog .modal-content .modal-body, .modal-dialog .modal-content .modal-header, .modal-dialog .modal-content .modal-footer{
    padding:1rem;
  }
  
  .configured-level{
    font-weight: bold;
  }
</style>

<script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/popper.js/1.12.9/umd/popper.min.js" integrity="sha384-ApNbgh9B+Y1QKtv3Rn7W3mgPxhU9K/ScQsAP7hUibX39j7fakFPskvXusvfa0b4Q" crossorigin="anonymous"></script>
<script src="https://maxcdn.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/4.0.0/js/bootstrap.min.js" integrity="sha384-JZR6Spejh4U02d8jOt6vLEHfe/JQGiRRSQQxSfFWpi1MquVdAyjUar5+76PVCmYl" crossorigin="anonymous"></script>
description: The form used to define the configuration for an SQL Database Integration.  This can support SQL Server, Oracle, or Postgres.

elements.name: Unique Individual Identifier Field Note
elements.text: <small>Which database field correlates to data found in MIR3 for user identification?</small>

elements.name: Qualification Note
elements.text:
Use {{Start Date}} and {{End Date}} to have Kinetic automatically replace them with database formatted date/time values since the last run time.
Example query: sys_updated_on>={{Start Date}}^sys_updated_on<{{End Date}}
Note: Any time the last run is greater than 60 minutes ago is considered a problem, and the times will be reset to the current time.

elements.name: Date Time Format Note
elements.text:
Create the date/time format to use based on Ruby STRFTIME capabilities.

List the options here. Make the the listing expandable so it doesn't appear on the screen at all times, and use iso8601 as the default???


  • %Y - Year with century (can be negative, 4 digits at least)
    -0001, 0000, 1995, 2009, 14292, etc.
    • %C - year / 100 (round down. 20 in 2009)
    • %y - year % 100 (00..99)

  • %m - Month of the year, zero-padded (01..12)
    • %_m blank-padded ( 1..12)
    • %-m no-padded (1..12)
  • %B - The full month name (``January'')
    • %^B uppercased (``JANUARY'')
  • %b - The abbreviated month name (``Jan'')
    • %^b uppercased (``JAN'')
  • %h - Equivalent to %b

  • %d - Day of the month, zero-padded (01..31)
    • %-d no-padded (1..31)
  • %e - Day of the month, blank-padded ( 1..31)

  • %j - Day of the year (001..366)

Time (Hour, Minute, Second, Subsecond): %H - Hour of the day, 24-hour clock, zero-padded (00..23) %k - Hour of the day, 24-hour clock, blank-padded ( 0..23) %I - Hour of the day, 12-hour clock, zero-padded (01..12) %l - Hour of the day, 12-hour clock, blank-padded ( 1..12) %P - Meridian indicator, lowercase (``am'' or ``pm'') %p - Meridian indicator, uppercase (``AM'' or ``PM'') %M - Minute of the hour (00..59) %S - Second of the minute (00..59) %L - Millisecond of the second (000..999) %N - Fractional seconds digits, default is 9 digits (nanosecond) %3N millisecond (3 digits) %15N femtosecond (15 digits) %6N microsecond (6 digits) %18N attosecond (18 digits) %9N nanosecond (9 digits) %21N zeptosecond (21 digits) %12N picosecond (12 digits) %24N yoctosecond (24 digits) Time zone: %z - Time zone as hour and minute offset from UTC (e.g. +0900) %:z - hour and minute offset from UTC with a colon (e.g. +09:00) %::z - hour, minute and second offset from UTC (e.g. +09:00:00) %:::z - hour, minute and second offset from UTC (e.g. +09, +09:30, +09:30:30) %Z - Equivalent to %:z (e.g. +09:00) Weekday: %A - The full weekday name (``Sunday'') %^A uppercased (``SUNDAY'') %a - The abbreviated name (``Sun'') %^a uppercased (``SUN'') %u - Day of the week (Monday is 1, 1..7) %w - Day of the week (Sunday is 0, 0..6) ISO 8601 week-based year and week number: The week 1 of YYYY starts with a Monday and includes YYYY-01-04. The days in the year before the first week are in the last week of the previous year. %G - The week-based year %g - The last 2 digits of the week-based year (00..99) %V - Week number of the week-based year (01..53) Week number: The week 1 of YYYY starts with a Sunday or Monday (according to %U or %W). The days in the year before the first week are in week 0. %U - Week number of the year. The week starts with Sunday. (00..53) %W - Week number of the year. The week starts with Monday. (00..53) Seconds since the Unix Epoch: %s - Number of seconds since 1970-01-01 00:00:00 UTC. %Q - Number of milliseconds since 1970-01-01 00:00:00 UTC. Literal string: %n - Newline character (\n) %t - Tab character (\t) %% - Literal ``%'' character Combination: %c - date and time (%a %b %e %T %Y) %D - Date (%m/%d/%y) %F - The ISO 8601 date format (%Y-%m-%d) %v - VMS date (%e-%b-%Y) %x - Same as %D %X - Same as %T %r - 12-hour time (%I:%M:%S %p) %R - 24-hour time (%H:%M) %T - 24-hour time (%H:%M:%S) %+ - date(1) (%a %b %e %H:%M:%S %Z %Y)

elements.name: Recurrence Display
elements.text:
Robot Display Here

Recurrence Description should be populated when the Robot form is updated

elements.name: Recurrence Modal

events.name: Display Recurrence Modal
Enable / Disable Recipient Fields and Set Escalation Level to 1

elements.name: Notification Data Mapping
elements.text:
Either a representation of data stored in a JSON object, or a subform with entires for each parameter / variable name from the notification.

Could do it like bridges, where you import the notification, then it "automatically" looks for parameters (or you can add them manually) into a separate datastore.  Then, you provide a value to the parameters in yet another datastore.  The task engine looks at the parameter values to generate it's data.  Overly complex?  How to keep updated?

elements.name: Recipients Container Header
elements.text:
Recipients
Use this syntax to replace a value with a field from ServiceNow: {{ServiceNow Field Name}}

events.name: Populate Notification Recipients

elements.name: Max Response Time Instruction
elements.text: <small>The Max Response Time will only be used for escalation levels not already defined by the message template; it does not override any existing timeout value. If a value is not provided for an escalationl level that is not predefined by the message template, 3600 will be used.</small>

events.name: Apply Escalation Recipients
events.runIf: values('Notification Method') === "firstResponseInfo" || values('Notification Method') === "calloutInfo" && values('Escalation Level') !== null

events.name: Apply Escalation Recipients
events.runIf: values('Notification Method') === "firstResponseInfo" || values('Notification Method') === "calloutInfo" && values('Escalation Level') !== null

events.name: Apply Escalation Recipients
events.runIf: values('Notification Method') === "firstResponseInfo" || values('Notification Method') === "calloutInfo" && values('Escalation Level') !== null

elements.name: SQL Statement - Initiation
elements.label: SQL statement to run upon initiation

elements.name: SQL Statement - Initiation Note
elements.text:
Use {{fieldname}} in the query to indicate fields that should be replaced at runtime with data from the database record. Use $$fieldname$$ to represent data that should be replaced with "working data". Standard working data field options are "Initiation Output".
Example:
UPDATE table SET notes='$$Initiation Output$$' WHERE id = '{{id}}'

elements.name: Initiation Custom Action Parameters Container Header
Initiation Standard Action Task Tree
elements.label: Standard Action Task Tree
elements.defaultValue: SQL Database Standard Notification Initiation Process

elements.name: Initiation Standard Action Parameters
elements.label: Standard Action Parameters
elements.defaultValue: {"Report Name":"Kinetic Notification Results", "Timezone":"UTC", "Responses Used":"1", "Success Responder Type":"3", "Detail Level":"1"}
elements.required: values('Notification Initiation Action') === "Standard Reporting" || values('Notification Initiation Action') === "Status Only"

elements.name: Initiation Standard Action Parameters Container
elements.visible: values('Notification Initiation Action') === "Standard Reporting" || values('Notification Initiation Action') === "Status Only"

elements.name: Initiation Standard Action Parameters Container Header
Initiation Standard Action Parameters Container Body
Initiation Standard Action Parameter Display
elements.visible: values('Notification Initiation Action') === "Standard Reporting" || values('Notification Initiation Action') === "Status Only"

elements.name: SQL Statement - Result
elements.label: SQL statement to run upon notification completion

elements.name: SQL Statement - Result Note
elements.text:
Use {{fieldname}} in the query to indicate fields that should be replaced at runtime with data from the database record. Use $$fieldname$$ to represent data that should be replaced with "working data". Standard working data field options are "Result Output".
Example:
UPDATE table SET notes='$$Result Output$$' WHERE id = '{{id}}'

elements.name: Assign Responder
elements.label: Assign Responder
elements.visible: (values('Notification Method') === "firstResponseInfo" || values('Notification Method') === "calloutInfo") && values('Notification Result Action') !== "None"
elements.required: (values('Notification Method') === "firstResponseInfo" || values('Notification Method') === "calloutInfo") && values('Notification Result Action') !== "None"

elements.name: Responder Lookup Required
elements.label: Responder Lookup Required (if MIR3 responder does correlate to database assignment field)

elements.name: SQL Statement - Responder Lookup Note
elements.text:
Use {{fieldname}} in the query to indicate fields that should be replaced at runtime with data from the database record. Use $$fieldname$$ to represent data that should be replaced with "working data". Standard working data field option is "responderValue" as returned from MIR3.

Example:
SELECT login_name FROM table_of_users WHERE somefield = '$$responderValue$$'

elements.name: SQL Statement - Assignment Lookup Note
elements.text:
Use {{fieldname}} in the query to indicate fields that should be replaced at runtime with data from the database record. Use $$fieldname$$ to represent data that should be replaced with "working data". If using the responder lookup, standard working data field options include the results of that call as follows "responder.<field_name>".

Example:
UPDATE table SET assignee = '$$responder.login_name$$' WHERE id='{{id}}'

elements.name: SQL Statement - Interim Note
elements.text:
Use {{fieldname}} in the query to indicate fields that should be replaced at runtime with data from the database record. Use $$fieldname$$ to represent data that should be replaced with "working data". Standard working data field options are "Interim Output".
Example:
UPDATE table SET notes='$$Interim Output$$' WHERE id = '{{id}}'
